title: 110_hr4650
content: The Act titled "Congressional Disclosures Protections Act of 2007" provides an alternative remedy for whistleblowers facing retaliation for disclosing to Congress. The "Congressional Disclosures Protections Act of 2007" amends Subchapter II of chapter 72 of title 5, United States Code, by adding a section on alternative remedies for whistleblowers. It defines compensatory damages and covered disclosures related to violations of laws, including title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The term 'employee' includes various individuals such as permanent, temporary, full or part-time employees, independent contractors, and professionals with institutional privileges, among others, who work for an organization that receives funding from the United States government. The term 'employee' includes various individuals working for organizations funded by the US government. Section 7211 outlines the protection of whistleblowers, defining interference and providing an alternative legal remedy for aggrieved employees. The court shall try the action with a jury upon request. The court must apply specific standards and may award triple damages, including lost wages and emotional distress. Pursuing an action under this subsection bars the employee from seeking other remedies under related sections. (b) Clerical Amendment.--The table of sections for chapter 72 of title 5, United States Code, is amended by inserting after the item relating to section 7211 the following: SEC. 3. RIGHT OF REPRESENTATION. Section 1212(a) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to provide legal representation to employees seeking relief under section 7212 of title 5. SEC. 4. AMENDMENT TO NO FEAR ACT. Paragraph (3) of section 203(a) of the Notification and Federal Employee Antidiscrimination and Retaliation Act of 2002 is amended to require agencies to reimburse expenses related to discrimination cases, including attorney's fees, salaries, and travel costs.
